717273f-a.text:
Broadway, north from but not including East Houston Street, showing horse drawn public coachs on Broadway, and a simularly drawn street car on Bleeker Street. The gas lamps shown in the foreground, at the curb, are in front of the Olympic Theatre, which is on the east side, between East
Houston and Bleeker Streets.
Ewing Galloway  1865
N.; ~ 287.

717269f-a.text:
Broadway, north from a point slightly south of Houston Street, showing vehicular and pedestrian traffic on this main artery of Manhattan during a spectacular period in the Citys history. Note the paved condition of the street bed and the lack of mechanical transportation; gas street lamps appearing midst overhead wire commnnications. The Grand Central Hotel which became the present Broadway Central Hotel is in the middistance with Grace P.E. Church farther northward, at the bend. The structures in the foreground, (both right and left sides) have disappeared today, vacant lots being tnereon, caused by demolition work during construction of the Independent Subway. This photograph, made from one of the early dry plates, comes from a book entitled "How to make
photographs" by T.C. Roche.
1883.
NN. Nc :

717271f.text:
Broadway, west side, at West Houston Street, as viewed in a northward direction and showing prominently the Cable Building at the N.W. corner of both streets. The three buildings shown on the left are Nos. 605607 (5-story Austin Building); No. 603, (8-story structure) and No. 601 (2-story structure). These were demolished in 1933 as a part of the
Eighth Ave. Subway construction.
May 25, 1904.
Brown Brothers.

717275f-a.text:
621-633 Broadway, at adjoining and north of the N.W. corner of West Houston Street, as seen across the clearance at the N.E. corner, caused by
the Eighth Ave. subway construction.
February 21, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

717270f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, at West Houston Street, showing a clearance at the S.W. corner of same, which was occupied by 2 buildings, Nos. 609-605 and 603 Broadway. Remaining is the 12-story Ayer Building (left) No. 599, which was adjoining the demolished structures. On the right appears a part of the Cable Building, No. 611-621 Broadway, a 9-story structure at the N.W. corner. This view is photographed in a southwestward direction from Crosby Street and shows clearances in the foreground on both sides of East Houston Street.

February 21, 1932

P. L. Sperr.

717274f-a.text:
Broadway, north across Houston Street, showing prominently the easterly side of this thoroghfare. Note the Olympic Theater at No. 622. This was demolished about 1880. In the background, at the bend at 10th Street, is Grace P.E. Church. Prior to 1880
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717276f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Houston
717276f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, between Houston and Bleecker Streets, showing the Olympic Theatre at No. 624. This structure was opened on November 18, 1856 and soon afterward re-christened Laura Keene's New Theatre. This name was attached to half a dozen theaters during the period from 1850 to 1870. She retired in 1863, and John Duff, who then became the manager, re-opened the house as Mrs. John Woods Olympic Theatre. After Mrs. Woods retirement in 1866 it had a checkered career and was demolished in 1880. Joseph Jefferson appeared here in the play "Our American Cousin" on its first performance on October 18, 1858.

Betw. 1863-66

Gift of Urbrook Collection

719450f-a.text:
East Houston Street, at the S.E. corner of Broadway, showing the 6-story Holt Building being rased. The entire block of buildings of which this one is a part were later demolished to make room for the construction of the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway).
September 26, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

724489f-a.text:
1-9 West Houston Street and b05-oCv Broadway, at the S.W. corner, a brick office building faced with iron. It probably dates
from the 1870's.
September 19, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

724491f-a.text:
Houston Street, south side, west from Broadway, just before the demolition of the entire south side west to Sixth Avenue.
September 19, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
